title: Creating, editing and deleting providers
content:
Create a provider

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as an administrator.
  2. Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers.
  3. Select the provider type from the panel on the left.
  4. Select the Gear icon     at the top right of the toolbar.
  5. Select Create Resource Provider. A window for creating provider will be displayed with required fields. Refer to the table below which gives the details of the required fields.
Item Description
Provider Type - for the items you can edit.

The type selected for the provider. Note that the Provider Type can't be changed after a provider is created.

The following are the available provider types:

  • Amazon AWS
  • Google Cloud Platform
  • Kubernetes
  • OpenText Database and Middleware Automation
  • OpenText Network Automation
  • OpenText Server Automation
  • OpenText Sitescope
  • OpenText UCMDB
  • Microsoft Azure
  • Microsoft SCVMM
  • Openstack
  • Terraform
  • VMware vCenter
Display Name The display name for the provider.
Description The description of the provider.
Image Select an image to be displayed as the provider icon.
Service Access Point

URL for connecting to the provider.

The following examples show how to connect to some common resource providers:

  • AWS - https://ec2.amazonaws.com:443
  • GCP - https://console.google.com:443
  • Kubernetes - https://<hostname or Kubernetes server IP>:443
  • DMA - https://<hostname or DMA server IP>:443
  • NA - https://<hostname or NA server IP>:443
  • SA - https://<hostname or SA server IP>:443
  • SiteScope - https://<hostname or SiteScope server IP>:8080
  • UCMDB - https://<hostname or UCMDB server IP>:8080
  • Azure - https://management.azure.com:443
  • SCVMM - https://<hostname or SCVMM server IP>:8100
  • Openstack - https://<hostname or Openstack server IP>:5000
  • Terraform - https://<hostname or Terraform server IP>:8080 or https://terraform.io
  • vCenter - https://<hostname or vCenter server IP>:443
Access Key ID This field is only applicable if you select Provider Type as Amazon AWS. The user ID for making programmatic calls to AWS or for using the AWS Command Line Interface or AWS Tools for PowerShell. For more information on configuring the Access Key ID, see Accessing AWS using your AWS credentials.
Secret Access Key This field is only applicable if you select Provider Type as Amazon AWS. The password for making programmatic calls to AWS or for using the AWS Command Line Interface or AWS Tools for PowerShell. Retype the password in the  field. For more information on configuring the Secret Access Key, see Accessing AWS using your AWS credentials. 
User ID

This field isn't applicable if you select Provider Type as Amazon AWS. The user ID for the specified Service Access Point. For Cloud Management, If you have deployed the Design and Deploy capability within a tenant and wish to leverage the advantages of Native SACM for your Cloud Services, you must configure a Deployment Resource Provider for UCMDB which allows for the integration between DND and UCMDB. For more information on configuration, see Configure DND-UCMDB integration.

It's recommended that you create a unique account in IdM and assign the UD/UCMDB OOB Admin or SuperAdmin role in UCMDB to this integration user such as dnd_integration so that the updates made to CIs in UCMDB will be clearly indicated as being made by DND. For more information on how to create integration users in containerized UD/UCMDB, see Typical workflow.
Password This field isn't applicable if you select Provider Type as Amazon AWS. The password for the specified Service Access Point. Retype the password in the Confirm Password field.
Enabled This value determines whether the provider will be selected when provisioning a new service. The setting is either Enabled (when selected) or Disabled (when cleared). When Disabled, the provider won't be selected when provisioning new services. Disabling a provider will have no effect on existing services that are using that provider.
Project This field is only applicable if you select Provider Type as Openstack. This field must be specified if the user has administrative privileges on the OpenStack system and can establish trusts for any authorized users during user login. If all OpenStack designs set enableUserContext to True, the Project can be left empty. Therefore, the subscriber must select the project at provisioning time from a set of projects authorized by the subscriber.
Domain This field is only applicable if you select Provider Type as Openstack. The domain in the OpenStack where operations will be performed. This domain must be configured for authentication in the same fashion as the consumer organizations for which this provider will be used.
User domain-scoped transport token This field is only applicable if you select Provider Type as Openstack. This value determines whether the provider user uses a domain scoped transport token for communication with Openstack.  The setting is either Enabled (when selected) or Disabled (when cleared). When Disabled, the provider uses a project scoped transport token. To use a domain scoped transport token, the provider must have admin rights.

You might come across additional provider specific fields that aren't listed in the table above. Populate the fields with relevant values and select Create.

While creating or updating a provider, the following validations are performed

  • For HTTPS connection - Provider URL and SSL Certificate. The certificate should be in PEM format (base64).
  • For HTTP connection - Provider URL.

On successful validation, the provider is created.

In case of validation failure, the following message is displayed.

The provider information you have entered couldn't be validated successfully. This is most likely due to an invalid/unreachable URL or an untrusted provider certificate. Continue anyway?

Select Yes to ignore the validation failure and continue creating the provider with the provided values.

Select No to correct the values. Perform the following corrective steps -

For HTTPS connection

  • Connect to control plane node and mount <config-volume> NFS volume on any directory (/mnt). Go to directory /mnt/../<config-volume>/certificate/cmp/source. Verify if SSL certificate is available in the directory. The certificate should be in PEM format (base64).
  • If SSL certificate isn't present, perform the following steps.
    • Obtain the SSL certificate from your provider. Connect to control plane node and copy the provider SSL certificate in the shared folder <config-volume>/certificate/cmp/source.
    • Delete and restart pod using the following commands. 
      kubectl scale deployment itom-cmp-config-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment itom-cmp-config-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=1

After restarting the pod, create the provider again. If you continue to get the error message, correct the URL and input parameters. Select Create after giving correct URL and input parameters. On successful validation, the provider is created.

For HTTP connection

Enter the correct URL and input parameters. Select Create. On successful validation, the provider will be created.

Tasks that can be performed on providers

  • Edit a providers - Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers. Select the provider from the right pane. Click the gear icon and select Edit. A window for editing the provider details is displayed. Edit the fields and select Save to save the changes.
  • Delete a provider - Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers. Select the provider from the right pane. Click the gear icon and select Delete. Click Yes in the confirmation dialog. A provider referenced by topology designs or by topology or sequenced service instances can't be deleted. All other providers can be deleted and their associations (to environments and to resource offerings) are automatically removed during the delete action. When you delete a provider, make sure that any resource offerings referenced by the provider and used in service design are still associated with at least one provider that can provision the resource offering.
  • Save as - You can create a new provider with the same specifications by selecting Save as option.
     
  • Refresh - You can refresh the provider details by selecting Refresh option.

Automatic resource synchronization

Resource synchronization fetches the available resources of a provider account. Once you create an Azure, AWS, GCP, or VMware vCenter provider, the resource synchronization happens automatically through a resource sync scheduler.

While creating a provider by referring to the steps provided above, the Enabled checkbox is selected by default. The platform creates a scheduler in OO Central. The first automatic resource synchronization will happen 5 minutes after the scheduler creation time. Following this, the scheduler will automatically perform the resource sync every 24 hours.

Below you can find few points that you should be aware about the resource sync scheduler:

  • If while creating a provider you clear the Enabled checkbox, resource sync scheduler won't be created in OO Central.
  • When you edit a resource provider and clear the Enabled checkbox, resource sync scheduler will get disabled.
  • When you edit a resource provider (Enabled checkbox is selected), the scheduler gets updated and will run a sync 5 minutes after the update.
  • When you edit the proxy properties (ProxyHost, ProxyPort, ProxyPassword, and ProxyUserName) under the Properties tab for a provider, the scheduler gets updated and will run a sync 5 minutes after the update.
  • When you delete a provider, the associated resource sync scheduler gets deleted from OO Central.
  • When deleting a provider, even if the Enabled checkbox is clear, the scheduler gets deleted from OO Central.
  • If you want to edit the provider or provider properties but don't want the scheduler to be updated, then you can go to OO Central and manually disable the scheduler under the SCHEDULER tab.
